Onboard Training Arrangement

Competence is emphasized heavily in the STCW Convention. Therefore, putting what the cadet has learnt during the educational process at the Maritime Higher Education Institution (MHEI) into reality is a crucial component of the STCW training program. The best method to train and educate them is onboard a seagoing ship above 500 GT (for Deck Cadets) or has an engine above 750KW (for Engine Cadets) while being supervised by someone with the necessary education and expertise. 

As a component of a structured maritime education and training program, onboard tasks must be documented in a Training Record Book (eTRB). The Cadet shall execute the tasks outlined in this book while being instructed, guided, and/or supervised by a Shipboard Training Officer (STO) onboard. The STO will review the cadet's progress and sign afterward. Regular monthly inspections of the eTRB shall be conducted by the Master/Chief Engineer as applicable. Once all responsibilities have been completed, the eTRB is handed over to the Onboard Training Supervisor (OTS) of the MHEI for validation. 

The STO shall observe the following guidelines:
The Company or Master shall appoint a Deck Officer to be the STO of the Deck Cadet while the Company or Chief Engineer shall appoint an Engine Officer to be the STO of the Engine Cadet.
Completion of the Training Record Book

The Administration and Commission approves the eTRB. eTRB and necessary forms must be registered and submitted by the Cadet to his or her MHEI. The e-Cadet system shall assign a control number on the eTRB of the Cadet. 

The Cadet must familiarize himself/herself with the objective and content of the eTRB after receiving the book, taking into consideration the Tasks, Criteria, and other relevant information outlined in the appropriate Sections. Under the guidance of the STO, the Cadet shall fill out the necessary information in the pertinent areas as soon as possible. 

On satisfactory completion, each of the assignments and tasks should be initialled by the Master/Chief Engineer or STO as appropriate. It is important for the Cadet to be aware that he/she may need to demonstrate this ability on several occasions before the Master/Chief Engineer or STO as appropriate are convinced that the standard has been achieved. 

The following shall also be observed in the completion of the eTRB. 

Common to Deck and Engine Cadets:
- Completion of the Onboard Training Task and Practices classified into different Categories:

* Sea Projects (SP) – are duties/tasks that can be performed by the cadets on their own time without interfering with ship’s operations. The sea projects are required to be 100% completed during the onboard training. \n* Operational Tasks (OT) – are duties/tasks wherein performance is dependent on actual ship operation or in accordance with the ship’s Planned Maintenance System. During onboard training, at least 70% of the operational tasks are expected to have been completed.

- Completion of Project Works (PW) – assignments to ensure progressive gaining of knowledge regarding the ship’s equipment and life-saving appliances carried onboard. PW is required to be completed at least 70% during the Cadet’s onboard training.
- Completion of the following Sections of the eTRB:

* Sea Service Record 
* Ship’s Particulars 
* Crew List Records 
* List of Training Records 
* Record of Cadet’s Onboard Familiarization 
* Emergency Preparedness Records 
* Safe Working Practices 
* Daily Journal of Watchkeeping Duties
For Deck Cadets:

- Not less than 12 months of seagoing service which shall include the performance of bridge watchkeeping duties for a period of not less than six (6) months under the supervision of the Master or a qualified deck officer, following a structured program of training onboard a seagoing ship of 500 gross tonnage or more, documented in the approved eTRB and Daily Journal of Watchkeeping Duties in accordance with the requirements of the STCW Convention, 1978, as amended. 
- Performance of bridge watchkeeping duties documented using the Daily Journal of Bridge Watchkeeping Duty prescribed the Maritime Administration. 
- Completion of the Records of Steering Section 
- Completion of the ColRegs Section
For Engine Cadets:

- A combined workshop skills training and an approved seagoing service of not less than 12 months as part of an approved training program, which shall include the performance of engine-room watchkeeping duties for a period of not less than six (6) months under the supervision of the Chief Engineer or a qualified engineer officer, following a structured program of training onboard a seagoing ship of 750kW propulsion power or more, documented in the approved eTRB and Daily Journal of Watchkeeping Duties in accordance with the requirements of the STCW Convention, 1978, as amended. \n- Performance of engine-room watchkeeping duties documented using the Daily Journal of Engine-room Watchkeeping Duty prescribed the Maritime Administration.
For Cadets onboard Oil Tanker Vessels:
- Completion of OT, SP, and PW of Supplemental Tasks for Oil Tanker Vessels
For Cadets onboard Chemical Tanker Vessels:
- Completion of OT, SP, and PW of Supplemental Tasks for Chemical Tanker Vessels
For Cadets onboard Combination Carrier Vessels:
- Completion of OT, SP, and PW of Supplemental Tasks for Combination Carrier Vessels
For Cadets onboard Gas Tanker Vessels:
- Completion of OT, SP, and PW of Supplemental Tasks for Gas Tanker Vessels
